description: From Middle English crevice, from Old French crevace, from crever (“to break, burst”), from Latin crepare (“to break, burst, crack”). Doublet of crevasse.

entries.meaning: A narrow crack or fissure, as in a rock or wall.
examples: I can't tell you how urbane and sprightly the old poll parrot was; and  […]  not a pocket, not a crevice, of pomp, humbug, respectability in him: he was fresh as a daisy.

verbs.description: crevice (third-person singular simple present crevices, present participle crevicing, simple past and past participle creviced)
